trans-unit.source: (should I split them into submodules?)
trans-unit.target: (should I split them into submodules?)

trans-unit.source: Algorithm.Coords.Converter from EMQ (GitHub mirror) is probably the GCJ leak. It is a JSP project "for demonstrating GIS systems", probably done by some government contractor.
trans-unit.target: Algorithm.Coords.Converter from EMQ (GitHub mirror) is probably the GCJ leak. It is a JSP project "for demonstrating GIS systems", probably done by some government contractor.

trans-unit.source: on4wp7 (2013) is the earliest rationalized GCJ (forward) implementation. No randomness is attempted.
trans-unit.target: on4wp7 (2013) is the earliest rationalized GCJ (forward) implementation. No randomness is attempted.

trans-unit.source: Restrictions on geographic data in China: this Wikipedia article outlines impacts and the "common secret" deobfuscation approach.
trans-unit.target: Restrictions on geographic data in China: this Wikipedia article outlines impacts and the "common secret" deobfuscation approach.

trans-unit.source: ChinaMapShift (2014) figured out the quick iterative inverse for GCJ. I learned about it via geoChina first and generalized it here.
trans-unit.target: ChinaMapShift (2014) figured out the quick iterative inverse for GCJ. I learned about it via geoChina first and generalized it here.

trans-unit.source: geoChina by caijun is a clear, concise implementation written in R. It features the iterative method from ChinaMapShift.
trans-unit.target: geoChina by caijun is a clear, concise implementation written in R. It features the iterative method from ChinaMapShift.

trans-unit.source: eviltransform is among the most popular cross-language soltions to the problem. It borrows its name directly from EvilTransform.cs, an early refactored version of a raw-flesh Java implementation found in "emq", some sort of government contractor GIS demo project.
trans-unit.target: eviltransform is among the most popular cross-language soltions to the problem. It borrows its name directly from EvilTransform.cs, an early refactored version of a raw-flesh Java implementation found in "emq", some sort of government contractor GIS demo project.

trans-unit.source: obfs(a) - obfs(b) is usually close to a - b. (The closer a and b are to each other, the better it works.)
trans-unit.target: obfs(a) - obfs(b) is usually close to a - b . (The closer a and b are to each other, the better it works.)

trans-unit.source: obfs(coord) is sort of close to coord.
trans-unit.target: obfs(coord) is sort of close to coord .

trans-unit.source: Iterate a bit: Get a rough guess somehow, and just use property 2 to estimate the remaining error as obfs(guess) - obfs(coord) and correct the guess.
trans-unit.target: Iterate a bit: Get a rough guess somehow, and just use property 2 to estimate the remaining error as obfs(guess) - obfs(coord) and correct the guess .

trans-unit.source: Run it backwards: obfs(coord) is never too far from coord, so just use  obfs(obfs(coord)) - obfs(coord) to estimate obfs(coord) - coord.
trans-unit.target: Run it backwards: obfs(coord) is never too far from coord , so just use   obfs(obfs(coord)) - obfs(coord) to estimate obfs(coord) - coord .

trans-unit.source: API
trans-unit.target: API

trans-unit.source: BD-09 is not very well sourced, but pycoordtrans (2014) seems to have it.
trans-unit.target: BD-09 is not very well sourced, but pycoordtrans (2014) seems to have it.

trans-unit.target: Feel free to print and sell t-shirts with the PDF file! It is put in the Public Domain, so you don't have to pay me for that. You can always fund my subversive activities on Patreon though.

trans-unit.source: I am planning on moving some of the comments on the algorithm found in my initial JavaScript implementation to the GitHub Wiki. I don't think anyone is going to be interested in copying comments on these idiocy when translating my implementation to other languages. ** If you are doing a translation, consider only using the comments from the PDF.
trans-unit.target: I am planning on moving some of the comments on the algorithm found in my initial JavaScript implementation to the GitHub Wiki. I don't think anyone is going to be interested in copying comments on these idiocy when translating my implementation to other languages. ** If you are doing a translation, consider only using the comments from the PDF.

trans-unit.source: Oh, and finally, here is an official news report on that particular [bleep] who came up with GCJ-02.
trans-unit.target: Oh, and finally, here is an official news report on that particular [bleep] who came up with GCJ-02.

trans-unit.source: PRCoord's APIs operate on, and returns, dedicated structures for coordinates. In API names, we generally refer to WGS-84 as wgs, GCJ-02 as gcj, and BD-09 (lat-lon) as bd.
trans-unit.target: PRCoord's APIs operate on, and returns, dedicated structures for coordinates. In API names, we generally refer to WGS-84 as wgs , GCJ-02 as gcj , and BD-09 (lat-lon) as bd .

trans-unit.source: PRCoords
trans-unit.target: ぞくもく

trans-unit.source: People's Rectified Coordinates (PRCoords) is a cross-language implementation of "public secret" Chinese coordinate obfuscation methods including GCJ-02 and BD-09, along with general deobfuscation methods previously established in ChinaMapShift, eviltransform, and geoChina. (Referring to the process of replacing straight lines with wavy ones as a "transform" is euphemism overdone.)
trans-unit.target: People's Rectified Coordinates (PRCoords) is a cross-language implementation of "public secret" Chinese coordinate obfuscation methods including GCJ-02 and BD-09, along with general deobfuscation methods previously established in ChinaMapShift, eviltransform, and geoChina. (Referring to the process of replacing straight lines with wavy ones as a "transform" is euphemism overdone.)

trans-unit.source: Physical PRCoords
trans-unit.target: 物理的なPRCoords

trans-unit.source: Public Domain
trans-unit.target: パブリックドメイン

trans-unit.source: Public Domain library for rectifying Chinese coordinates (gcj-02/bd-09)
trans-unit.target: 中国座標修正のためのパブリックドメインライブラリ (GCJ-02/BD-09)

trans-unit.source: See also
trans-unit.target: 参照:

trans-unit.source: Since June 2016, eviltransform contains numerous parameter errors that compromise its output, especially for BD-09. See googollee/eviltransform#43, #53 and #44 for corrections. As of June 2019 these problems are not fixed.
trans-unit.target: Since June 2016, eviltransform contains numerous parameter errors that compromise its output, especially for BD-09. See googollee/eviltransform#43, #53 and #44 for corrections. As of June 2019 these problems are not fixed.

trans-unit.source: Sources
trans-unit.target: 情報源

trans-unit.source: The "in China" sanity check
trans-unit.target: 中国では」サニティーチェック

trans-unit.source: The obfuscations generally have these properties to maintain basic usefulness:
trans-unit.target: 難読化は一般的に、基本的な有用性を維持するためにこれらの特性を持っています。

trans-unit.source: There is an "insane" sanity check intended to approximate the range of Google and Baidu's distortion, intended for use by IITC: js/insane_is_in_china.js. It is basically a ray-casting polygon check with 70 vertices. You, as the caller, should still be responsible for telling whether a point is part of the gov-screwed Chinese data.
trans-unit.target: There is an "insane" sanity check intended to approximate the range of Google and Baidu's distortion, intended for use by IITC: js/insane_is_in_china.js . It is basically a ray-casting polygon check with 70 vertices. You, as the caller, should still be responsible for telling whether a point is part of the gov-screwed Chinese data.

trans-unit.source: There is some randomness in the GCJ deltas on both axes: one sin invocation and one LCG. Each add a maximum of 1 meter of error.
trans-unit.target: There is some randomness in the GCJ deltas on both axes: one sin invocation and one LCG. Each add a maximum of 1 meter of error.

trans-unit.source: Typically PRCoords is only supposed to be ran on obfuscated input data, which are primarily Chinese coordinates. For this reason, initial implementations include this very very rough sanity check that spans a rectangular region on a mercator-projected map. This check can be overridden by passing a boolean value, or may be not at all implemented in certain languages if I am not in the right mood for doing silly things.
trans-unit.target: Typically PRCoords is only supposed to be ran on obfuscated input data, which are primarily Chinese coordinates. For this reason, initial implementations include this very very rough sanity check that spans a rectangular region on a mercator-projected map. This check can be overridden by passing a boolean value, or may be not at all implemented in certain languages if I am not in the right mood for doing silly things.

trans-unit.source: You can print out a minimal copy of PRCoords with this PDF file. I am working on some better options in issue #2. A fairly simple tote bag with an older version of the PDF is available from Teespring.
trans-unit.target: You can print out a minimal copy of PRCoords with this PDF file. I am working on some better options in issue #2. A fairly simple tote bag with an older version of the PDF is available from Teespring.
